Dolphins perform better in communication experiments than chimps. The problem is that chimps have no vocal chords wheras we have some very flexible ones. Therefore chimps are at a communication disadvantage. Dolphins have an even richer communication range than our vocal chords provide and they use it.
 
 In lab studies experimenters have responed with high pitch sounds when the dolphins make one. This set up a kind of conversation. But when the dolphin went out of human hearing range no response was made. The result was that the dolphin quickly learnt what the human hearing range was and didn't try and communicate outside that range again.
 
 There are also quite complex social interactions and reasoning observed in the wild. One example involves a school of dolphins which travelled into a certain bay once in a while. On one occasion a boat was in the bay to study them. They found that as the dolphins approached the bay they stopped and lots of dolphin "chatter" was detected. Then one of them left the group and swam to the ship and around it. After it was finished it returned to the group and more chatter was heard for a few more minutes until the whole group then continued on its way to the bay.
 
 Now you can make of that what you want. Obviously without "mind probes" nothing can be known for sure but it does seem that the school detected the boat in the bay, discussed it, and sent a scout to see what it was. WHen the scout got back they discussed it again and continued on their way.
 
 Unfortunately for dolphins they have no hands and fingers so even if they are near human intelligence they will never be able to build things or create fire.

 There's too much that's already been said in the thread for me to express each point of disagreement. E.F, just happened to putup another few points.
 
 1) Chimps have been found form alliances with other chimps to gain power over their group, and overthrow the leader. 
 
 2) Chimps retaliate against other chimps that have in some way "persecuted them". This is usually done through alliances within their group. 
 (We could call that revenge.)
 
 3) Strategic alliances can be formed immediately, depending upon the type of event in a group, or they can take weeks, or months to develop. 
 
 4) Chimps recognize themselves in a mirror. They are self-aware.
 
 5) An Orangutan was shown (through a controlled experiment) to be aware
 of what a person did NOT know, AND to direct the person to discover what they did not know.
 
 6) Chimps have been shown to understand the concept of zero.
 
 7) Chimps have been shown to be capable of doing simple arithmetic, using symbols (after they were taught the same arithmetic using the a number of objects to represent that number of ojbects. ) This shows symbolic reasoning.
 
 8) Chimps also understand symbolic reasoning when presented with a combination of words in the same sentence that they have never heard before. That is, they understood the meaning of the sentence and carried out the task.
 
 9) Chimps are believed to have the reasoning abilities of a human that is 2 years old.
 
 Lastly, scientists that have been working with chimps have had to redefine the meaning of the word "conscious" as it applies to defining a conscious being, that is believed to separate ourselves from chimps. However, the current definition used for a "conscious" being, when it applies to separating us from chimps is so complex, that it was difficult for me to understand, and I could not possibly attempt to even paraphrase what the definition currently is.
 
 Even a lowly creature like an African Grey Parrot is so smart, I think you'd have a hard time believing me, if I described the results of some research that's been done over the past 20 years, and continues today.
 
 Sources: Jane Goodal, and various NOVA Specials on PBS.

 Here's how they found out. They set a man and a chimp at a table, and taught a chimp to play the shell game, where a pea is hidden under one of three cups. The man, however, can see where the pea is, and he points to the cup each time.
 
 The chimp quickly learns to take the indicated cup, and both he and the human get a treat each time they win.
 
 Then, one day, they come in and the positions are switched. Chimps don't miss a beat, but immediately point to the right cup.

 I suspect that Chimp 'language' can be better explained as immitation, observation of the keepers, learned response and the workings of an undoubtably intelligent mind.  Why do the chimps have it? It's useful. They are observed cooperatively hunting, and signalling to each other, to close in on their prey.
 
 We have more subtle uses for it. Sometimes chimps do to. Apes are capable of lying. Those who can sign will do it, sometimes.

 
 B. F. Skinner would have stated that the chimp learned what to do by process of reward. It learned both positions, the first by doing the second by observation. The chimp associated the "pea" with a reward and therefore instinctively understood that finding the pea resulted in reward not pointing to the cup. 
 
 Skinner would have said it is a learned response, simply, and would never have come to a conclusion about empathy. I say this as I was trained as a skinnerian Behaviorist.

I have no problem in principle with the claim that Chimps can understand language. However language understanding is a very complicated activity for which sections of the human brain have evolved the necessary instincts. Since there is no evidence that Chimps actually use language in their natural state I am therefore dubious of any claims that Chimps are understanding the language as language rather than simply as symbolic gestures or sounds.
 
 I suspect that Chimp 'language' can be better explained as immitation, observation of the keepers, learned response and the workings of an undoubtably intelligent mind. Just as the famous calculated horse was revealed as a clever trick of the horse responding the crowd, so I believe Chimp 'language' will be explained. Stephen Pinker's The Language Instinct contains a very interesting discussion of Chimp 'language'; if you can get access to a copy it's a fascinating and informative book in general, and in particular on Chimp language claims.
 
 I'm saying Chimp, I should be saying ape, as you correctly pointed out some of the supposed instances have involved Orang-utans.

A similar occurrence was noted when, in 1962, several Lockheed Aircraft Corporation scientists erected a similar barrier across a channel, this time with stronger microphones.  "If there was ever a moment when man was only an animal, we can if we choose make a fancy picture of his career transferred to some other animal. An entertaining fanasia might be made in which elephants built in elephantine architecture, with towers and turrets like tusks and trunks, cities beyond the scale of any colossus. A pleasant fable might be conceived in which a cow had developed a costume, and put on four boots and two pairs of trousers. We could imagine a Supermonkey more marvellous than any Superman, a quadrumanous creature carving and painting with his hands and cooking and carpentering with his feet. But if we are considering what did happen, we shall certainly decide that man has distanced everything else with a distance like that of the astronomical spaces and a speed like that of the still thunderbolt of the light."
 
 "It is the simple truth that man does differ from the brutes in kind and not in degree; and the proof of it is here; that it sounds like a truism to say that the most primitive man drew a picture of a monkey and that it sounds like a joke to say that the most intelligent monkey drew a picture of a man. Something of division and disproportion has appeared; and it is unique. Art is the signature of man." 
 
 "When all is said, the main fact that the record of the reindeer men attests, along with all other records, is that the reindeer man could draw and the reindeer could not. If the reindeer man was as much an animal as the reindeer, it was all the more extraordinary that he could do what all other animals could not. If he was an ordinary product of biological growth, like any other beast or bird, then it is all the more extraordinary that he was not in the least like any other beast or bird. He seems rather more supernatural as a natural product than as a supernatural one...For in the plain matter like the pictures there is in fact not a trace of any such development or degree. Monkeys did not begin pictures and men finish them; Pithecanthropus did not draw a reindeer badly and Homo Sapiens draw it well. The higher animals did not draw better and better portraits; the dog did not paint better in his best period than in his early bad manner as a jackal; the wild horse was not an Impressionist and the race-horse a Post-Impressionist. All we can say of this notion of reproducing things in shadow or representative shape is that it exists nowhere in nature except in man; and that we cannot even talk about it without treating man as something separate from nature. In other words, every sane sort of history must begin with man as man, a thing standing absolute and alone."
 
 "In the land lit by that neighboring star, whose blaze is the broad daylight, there are many and very various things, motionless and moving. There moves among them a race that is in its relation to others a race of gods. The fact is not lessened but emphasised because it can behave like a race of demons...It is customary to insist that man resembles the other creatures. Yes; and that very resemblance he alone can see. The fish does not trace the fish-bone pattern in the fowls of the air; or the elephant and the emu compare skeletons. Even in the sense in which man is at one with the universe it is an utterly lonely universality. The very sense that he is united with all things is enough to sunder him from all."
 
 "The more we really look at man as an animal, the less he will look like one.
 
 The simplest truth about man is that he is a very strange being; almost in the sense of being a stranger here on the earth...He has much more of the external appearance of one bringing alien habits from another land than of a mere growth of this one. He has an unfair advantage and an unfair disadvantage. He cannot sleep in his own skin; he cannot trust his own instincts. He is at once a creator moving miraculous hands and fingers and a kind of cripple. He is wrapped in artificial bandages called clothes; he is propped on artificial crutches called furniture. His mind has the same doubtful liberties and the same wild limitations. Alone among the animals, he is shaken with the beautiful madness called laughter...Alone among the animals he feels...the mystery of shame. Whether we praise these things as natural to man or abuse them as artificial in nature, they remain in the same sense unique. This is realised by the whole popular instinct called religion."
 
 "Suppose that one bird out of a thousand birds began to do one of the thousand things that man had already done even in the morning of the world; and we can be quite certain that the onlooker would not regard such a bird as a mere evolutionary variety of the other birds; he would regard it as a fearful wild-fowl indeed...That bird would tell the augurs, not of something that would happen, but of something that had happened. That something would be the appearance of a mind with a new dimension of depth; a mind like that of man. If there be no God, no other mind  could conceivable have foreseen it...There may be a broken trail of stones and bones faintly suggesting the development of the human body. There is nothing even faintly suggesting such a development of the human mind. It was not and it was; we know not in what instant or infinity of years. Something happened; and it has all the appearance of a transaction outside time."
 
 THE EVERLASTING MAN  by G.K. CHESTERTON

 That is not to say that I don't understand the concept that every organism on earth is equally as evolved from the original life. But that concept doesn't apply to individual derived characteristics. My compound eyes are not as evolved as those of a lobster. In fact, I don't have compound eyes.

Originally Posted by maximus
 "If there was ever a moment when man was only an animal, we can if we choose make a fancy picture of his career transferred to some other animal. An entertaining fanasia might be made in which elephants built in elephantine architecture, with towers and turrets like tusks and trunks, cities beyond the scale of any colossus. A pleasant fable might be conceived in which a cow had developed a costume, and put on four boots and two pairs of trousers. We could imagine a Supermonkey more marvellous than any Superman, a quadrumanous creature carving and painting with his hands and cooking and carpentering with his feet. But if we are considering what did happen, we shall certainly decide that man has distanced everything else with a distance like that of the astronomical spaces and a speed like that of the still thunderbolt of the light."
 
 "It is the simple truth that man does differ from the brutes in kind and not in degree; and the proof of it is here; that it sounds like a truism to say that the most primitive man drew a picture of a monkey and that it sounds like a joke to say that the most intelligent monkey drew a picture of a man. Something of division and disproportion has appeared; and it is unique. Art is the signature of man." 
 
 "When all is said, the main fact that the record of the reindeer men attests, along with all other records, is that the reindeer man could draw and the reindeer could not. If the reindeer man was as much an animal as the reindeer, it was all the more extraordinary that he could do what all other animals could not. If he was an ordinary product of biological growth, like any other beast or bird, then it is all the more extraordinary that he was not in the least like any other beast or bird. He seems rather more supernatural as a natural product than as a supernatural one...For in the plain matter like the pictures there is in fact not a trace of any such development or degree. Monkeys did not begin pictures and men finish them; Pithecanthropus did not draw a reindeer badly and Homo Sapiens draw it well. The higher animals did not draw better and better portraits; the dog did not paint better in his best period than in his early bad manner as a jackal; the wild horse was not an Impressionist and the race-horse a Post-Impressionist. All we can say of this notion of reproducing things in shadow or representative shape is that it exists nowhere in nature except in man; and that we cannot even talk about it without treating man as something separate from nature. In other words, every sane sort of history must begin with man as man, a thing standing absolute and alone."
 
 "In the land lit by that neighboring star, whose blaze is the broad daylight, there are many and very various things, motionless and moving. There moves among them a race that is in its relation to others a race of gods. The fact is not lessened but emphasised because it can behave like a race of demons...It is customary to insist that man resembles the other creatures. Yes; and that very resemblance he alone can see. The fish does not trace the fish-bone pattern in the fowls of the air; or the elephant and the emu compare skeletons. Even in the sense in which man is at one with the universe it is an utterly lonely universality. The very sense that he is united with all things is enough to sunder him from all."
 
 "The more we really look at man as an animal, the less he will look like one.
 
 The simplest truth about man is that he is a very strange being; almost in the sense of being a stranger here on the earth...He has much more of the external appearance of one bringing alien habits from another land than of a mere growth of this one. He has an unfair advantage and an unfair disadvantage. He cannot sleep in his own skin; he cannot trust his own instincts. He is at once a creator moving miraculous hands and fingers and a kind of cripple. He is wrapped in artificial bandages called clothes; he is propped on artificial crutches called furniture. His mind has the same doubtful liberties and the same wild limitations. Alone among the animals, he is shaken with the beautiful madness called laughter...Alone among the animals he feels...the mystery of shame. Whether we praise these things as natural to man or abuse them as artificial in nature, they remain in the same sense unique. This is realised by the whole popular instinct called religion."
 
 "Suppose that one bird out of a thousand birds began to do one of the thousand things that man had already done even in the morning of the world; and we can be quite certain that the onlooker would not regard such a bird as a mere evolutionary variety of the other birds; he would regard it as a fearful wild-fowl indeed...That bird would tell the augurs, not of something that would happen, but of something that had happened. That something would be the appearance of a mind with a new dimension of depth; a mind like that of man. If there be no God, no other mind  could conceivable have foreseen it...There may be a broken trail of stones and bones faintly suggesting the development of the human body. There is nothing even faintly suggesting such a development of the human mind. It was not and it was; we know not in what instant or infinity of years. Something happened; and it has all the appearance of a transaction outside time."
 
 THE EVERLASTING MAN by G.K. CHESTERTON

Chimps laugh. Like humans, they do this (among other times) when they are tickled. Apes seem to enjoy tickling games. Humans are no exception.

 
 But how many times has an ape told you a joke or drawn you a funny picture? How many of them have written a comedy or told you why they were laughing? How many of them read the "funny" papers? How many laugh voluntarily and not simply as an involuntary reflex?

What separates man from ape?
 
 Man is a spiritual being, with a capacity for thought and language. he totally dominates the animal world and has been able to plumb the heights and depths of the entire universe, even to the extent of investigating, and partially understanding, his own DNA. Paradoxically, however, we are always wanting to deny the divine in our natures: to understand, measure and judge ourselves according to that which is lower rather than higher. That very ability to choose the beliefs which govern our lives sets us apart from all other animals.
 
 According to the bible, the highest reality is God, and man was created by him. He was made 'in his image, after his likeness'. Darwinism attempts to contradict the obvious differences between man and the other animals by suggesting that in the past the differences were much smaller. It is a philosophy which seeks to minimise the divine and maximise the physical, in the hope that it will seem plausible to imagine an evolutionary transition from animal to human.
 
 The simplest explanation for the origin of man's intelligence and capabilities is that he proceeded from a supreme intelligence, an intellect of unfathomable magnitude, a vast reservoir of cognitive capabilities.
 
 the question is not what separates man from ape, but rather, what separates ape from man?.

Man is a spiritual being, with a capacity for thought and language.

 Even if you are correct, what does the first have to do with the other two? Even if you are correct, how do you observe this spiritual nature. How big is it? Does it have mass? Is the spiritual nature of everyone the same?
 
he totally dominates the animal world...

 Really? So did T. rex. Are you saying that we differ because we are at the top of the food chain?
 
...and has been able to plumb the heights and depths of the entire universe, even to the extent of investigating, and partially understanding, his own DNA.

 But I don't think that answers the question. So, we're pretty smart. Other animals are smart too, just not as smart as we are. And I'm not sure how understanding something about DNA is what makes us different from chimps.
 
Paradoxically, however, we are always wanting to deny the divine in our natures:

 You are? I'm not. It just doesn't have any place in science. Science studies the natural, not the supernatural, so answering a question by claiming supernatural intervention doesn't answer the question at all.
 
to understand, measure and judge ourselves according to that which is lower rather than higher.

 But to claim divine intervention or supernatural powers doesn't measure or judge anything. Does everyone have the same amount of "divine" in his nature? How does one measure that?
 
That very ability to choose the beliefs which govern our lives sets us apart from all other animals.

 Sure. But I don't think that answers the question either. What you are saying is that there is no difference except that some supernatural being intervened. POOF! Great. Unless you can quantify all of that you are just avoiding the question.
 
According to the bible, the highest reality is God, and man was created by him.

 What does the Bible have to do with it? You can't even show that the Bible is inspired by God. You can claim so, but you can't support that claim except by faith.
 
He was made 'in his image, after his likeness'.

 POOF! And you still haven't answered the question. I guess then we should ask how does God differ from a chimp?
 
Darwinism attempts to contradict the obvious differences between man and the other animals by suggesting that in the past the differences were much smaller.

 That's nonsense. Darwinism makes no such attempt. In fact, Darwinism attempts to explain differences based on observations made in the real world. No magic involved.
 
It is a philosophy which seeks to minimise the divine and maximise the physical,

 More nonsense. First of all, in a strict manner of speaking, Darwinism existed in the last half of the 19th century. It was replaced, or rather subsumed, by the synthesis of genetics and Darwinism. It became known as neo-Darwinism. I have always just called it evolutionary biology. And now, it's not a philosophy. It is a body of knowledge based on real observations of the natural world. The theories offer explanations for the many, many observations. And like all sciences, it is linked to other fields of study by supporting evidence. And only a fool would suggest that the divine is subject to scientific inquiry. That is why evolutionary doesn't seek to minimize it. The divine is relevant to evolutionary biology in exactly the same manner that it is relevant to plumbing. Neither deals with God because both lack the tools to observe God. Neither denies God.
 
...in the hope that it will seem plausible to imagine an evolutionary transition from animal to human.

 Nope. There isn't any hope. If the evidence pointed to some other origin for humanity, science would accept that. Science, evolutionary biology included, makes observations, forms hypotheses, makes predictions and then tests those predictions.
 
The simplest explanation for the origin of man's intelligence and capabilities is that he proceeded from a supreme intelligence, an intellect of unfathomable magnitude, a vast reservoir of cognitive capabilities.

 Great! Please enumerate the steps by which this was accomplished. So far you have offered an assertion of magic. You have avoided answering the question.
 
the question is not what separates man from ape, but rather, what separates ape from man?.

 Is that supposed to mean something or are you just trying to look wise?
 
 In fact, I'll give an answer to the question. Bipedalism. I think this may have been the key. It offered a better position to look for danger, it freed the hands so that more food might be carried to a safe place, it reduced the total body surface that was exposed to the direct sun, thereby making temperature regulation easier, it was a more efficient means for travel. And with the hands free, it made too use possible and that may have made a bigger brain an advantage.
Certainly one could consider that Man is the only animal with a religion. That would definitely be considered a difference. I am unaware of any other animals with such a thing.

Depends what you mean by religion, they are perfectly capable of beleiving in something that isn't there as seen by the caution herbivores display when drinking at waterholes, they don't know there is a crocodile or tiger waiting for them, but they behave as if this hypthetical hunter was there. They also pass various traditions down to their offspring in the form of tools and huntering techniques- rest of religion is just rules for living in big groups and social control mechanisms. You have to consider how much of human religion can be explained away as these kind of things before you start explaining away animal behaviour as less complex behaviour
